"Throughout the course of a rehearsal process, Stage Managers need to record the " "blocking/choreography of scenes as the directors and actors stage them. This process " "is highly tedious on paper and often is slower than the pace of rehearsal. Furthermore, " "the staging will often go through many revisions, which can clutter a paper record with " "several edits.

"
"Blocking Tracker makes the beleaguered Stage Manager’s life easier. " "Instead of countless pages of half-erased pencil marks and scratched-out directions, " "we provide a simple image template onto which actor blocking can be recorded simply " "and efficiently, using modular icons that can be changed with ease.

"
"Blocking Tracker is the creation of Ben Fuligni and Selena Groh for Tufts University’s " "Mobile Development course (Fall 2017) taught by Ming Chow. " "Much gratitude and acknowledgement to Ming Chow and our fellow students.

"

"To add new blocking:
" "1. Highlight the portion of text which is associated with the blocking.
" "2. Press the "Track Blocking" button. This will take you to the blocking page, where you can record the actors' positions at that moment.
" "
To revisit previously entered blocking:
" "1. Highlight just the footnote in the script associated with the blocking. For instance, "[1]".
" "2. Press the "Track Blocking" button. This will take you to the blocking associated with that footnote.
"

"To add a new actor dot:
" "Press the "+" button and enter an actor label. By default, the actor dot appears in the top left.
" "
To move an actor dot:
" "Tap once on a dot to select it (it will change colors when selected), then tap again where you want to move it.
" "
To delete an actor dot:
" "Tap once on a dot to select it (it will change colors when selected), then press the trash can icon to delete it.
" "
To save the blocking and return to the script:
" "Press the save icon to save the dots' positions where they currently are, and associate them with the selected point in the script.
"
